title: Free-body diagrams - car pushing blocks up incline

content.question: A toy car pushes two identical blocks, Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> and Block <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>, up an inclined ramp at a constant velocity, as shown. The force of friction between the incline and the blocks is negligible. Which of the following pairs of free-body diagrams best represent the free-body diagrams for Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> and Block <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>?

choices.label: Two free body diagrams are shown. The first free body diagram is labeled Block A and there are 4 arrows extending from a dot. The first arrow is long and extends upward and to the left. The second arrow is long and extends vertically downward. The third arrow is short and extends downward and to the left. The fourth arrow is of medium length and extends upward and to the right. The second free body diagram is labeled Block B and there are 3 arrows extending from a dot. The first arrow is long and extends upward and to the left. The second arrow is long and extends vertically downward. The third arrow is of medium length and extends upward and to the right

The second free body diagram, labeled Block B, is identical to the first diagram.

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
